questions.question_text:
An enterprise has these three WAN connections:
• public Internet
• business Internet
• MPLS

An engineer must configure two available links to route traffic via both links. Which configuration achieves this objective?

discussion.content:
One thing is to have many paths in your routing information base (that's how many is sending to you the vsmart = send-path-limit), other one to have them installed in your routing table. for me is ecmp-limit 2 equal cost multi path. If all the parameters are equals for a route then both are installed, it should send the traffic by default through both paths. Is what i think. Thanks and good luck to all of you. 

OMP Send-Path-Limit is a configuration parameter that defines the maximum number of equal-cost vroutes that a vSmart controller or a vEdge router advertises to its OMP peers


the number of routes that get installed in the routing tables is subject to another OMP parameter called ecmp-limit.

Not sure which one is correct but I've found this:

The send-path-limit parameter defines the maximum number of best-paths that can be advertised.
The ecmp-limit parameter defines the maximum number of best paths that can be installed in the routing table.

Selected Answer: A
Option B, omp no shutdown send-path-limit 2, is not correct because the send-path-limit parameter controls the number of equal-cost routes that a vEdge router advertises to its neighbors, not the number of routes that it installs in its own FIB.

The send-path-limit parameter is primarily used to reduce the amount of routing information that is exchanged between vEdge routers. By limiting the number of routes that are advertised, the network can reduce the amount of bandwidth that is consumed by routing updates.

Selected Answer: A
Agree, it has to be A

Selected Answer: A
the number of routes that get installed in the routing tables is subject to another OMP parameter called ecmp-limit.
so I believe correct is A

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer

IMO it's A

If you want to route traffic (which means to send packets on a different links), you need to use ecmp-limit, because it affects the data plane. The question does not mention advertising prefixes (which is configured with send-path-limit). Send-path-limit would advertise two prefixes to vSmart and it would pass them to other EDGEs, so they could load balance, but only if they have ecmp-limit >= 2.

send-path-limit
Configure the maximum number of equal-cost routes that are advertised per prefix (on vSmart controllers and vEdge routers only).

It should be B.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/sdwan/command/sdwan-cr-book/config-cmd.html#r_send_path_limit_3834.xml

choices.A: Branch to be added as Client Sites and H.Q as DIA.
choices.C: Branch to be added as DIA and H.Q as Client Site.

This is a simple case of syntax, historically (hub and spoke) in SD-WAN gateway and client.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An enterprise decides to use the Cisco SD-WAN Cloud onRamp for SaaS feature and utilize H.Q site Biz iNET to reach SaaS Cloud for branch C, currently reaching SaaS Cloud directly. Which role must be assigned to devices at both sites in vManage Cloud Express for this solution to work?
Which action is performed during the onboarding process when a WAN Edge router is connected to ZTP server ztp.viptela.com?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
A: There is no such thing as WAN Edge Cloud Center
B: Correct
C: WAN Edge Never connects with IPSEC Tunnel to vSmart. 
D: WAN Edge establishes OMP and control connections (TLS / DTLS) after successful authentication from vBond. Vbond is first in line.

Selected Answer: B
Answer should be B!

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B?

choices.B: The router receives its vBond Orchestrator information.
choices.A: The router is connected to WAN Edge Cloud Center.
choices.D: The router is connected to vSmart Controller via a DTLS/TLS tunnel.
choices.C: The router is synced with vSmart Controller via an IPsec tunnel.

discussion.content:
Bad worded question. 
for vs. when

D, is configured like "encapsulation ipsec preference" under interface tunnel.

example:
 tunnel-interface
 encapsulation ipsec preference 50

Selected Answer: D
Answer can also be found here:

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/routers/sd-wan/217479-omp-best-path-selection-peculiarities-an.html#anc2

Best Path Selection:
1: Route Resolvability
2: Highest Route Preference
3: Highest TLOC Preference

Since the question says specifically equal for route preference, the next in line is Highest TLOC Preference.

Selected Answer: D
Correct
https://www.networkacademy.io/ccie-enterprise/sdwan/omp-best-path-selection

questions.question_text: Which OMP route is selected for equal OMP route preference values on WAN Edge routers?

choices.B: route with origin type of static
choices.D: route with higher TLOC preference value
choices.C: route with lower TLOC preference value
choices.A: route with origin type of connected

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct: https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/vManage_Help/Release_18.4/Dashboard/Dashboard

It seems to have changed, but none of other answer is correct anyway...

comments.content:
In that link below it states
In Cisco vManage Release 20.6.x and earlier releases, Cisco vManage has the following behavior:

The WAN Edge Health pane is part of the Dashboard > Main Dashboard page.

The Good, Fair, and Poor statuses are titled Normal, Warning, and Error, respectively.

A hardware node is classified as normal if it uses 70% of total memory or total CPU instead of 75%. Similarly, it is classified as in a warning state if it uses between 75% and 90% of total memory or total CPU instead of the range of 70%-90%.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Normal—Number of routers with memory, hardware, and CPU in normal state. Using less than 70% of total memory or total CPU is classified as normal.

https://sdwan-docs.cisco.com/Product_Documentation/vManage_Help/Release_18.4/Dashboard/Dashboard

questions.question_text: Which percentage of total memory or total CPU usage for a device is classified as normal in the WAN Edge Health pane?
